title-group.article-title: Comparative Cows: Or, Reading "The Hamlet" for Its Residues

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2003 The Johns Hopkins University Press

Hegel notes, "Precisely in labour, where there seems to be some outsider's mind and ideas involved, the bondsman becomes aware, through his rediscovery of himself by himself, of having and being a 'mind of his own"' (187)
Early in The Yiamlet, the narrator comments of Varner, "He was a farmer, a usurer, a veterinarian" (5).
Milliei M. Kidd, "The Dialogic Perspective in William Faulkner's The Hamlet," Mississippi Quarterly 44 [1991]: 309-20

The Life of William Faulkner [Oxford: Blackwell, 1996], 257

Kartiganer makes a similar point, more emphati- cally, "Ratliff is the key . .. for his development in the novel is its most vivid figure for the workings of a mythic fiction. His progress is to lock himself into the myths of Frenchman's Bend. He moves from his role as community poet, passively telling its comic history from his perch just outside it, to his final role as active defender of the community, challenging Flem Snopes" (118)
Roger L. Ransom and Richard Sutch, One Kind of Freedom: The Economic Consequences of Emancipation (Cambridge: Cambridge Univ. Press, 1977), 137.
Ransom and Sutch, 237-43

Ransom and Sutch note that one survey suggests that merchants charged an average interest rate for credit of 59.4% per annum. "Interest rates in the neighbourhood of 60 percent must be judged enormous when compared with credit charges at other times and other places in American history. Short-term interest rates in New York City during this period ranged generally from 4 to 6 percent and never ranged above 8 percent, we can safely assume 10 percent as the maximum cost of the funds involved" (130)
Thomas D. Clark, Pills, Petticoats and Plows (New York: The Bobbs-Merill Com- pany, 1944), 316-30
Joesph Urgo, "Faulkner's Real Estate: Land and Literary Speculation in The Hamlet," Mississippi Quarterly 48 (1995): 443-57.
